facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 19 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 19 of 1952. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated 19th June, 1950,

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Decree dated 19th June 1950 of Calcutta High Court, Das and Guha JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated 19th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta  Das and Guha JJ.  in

facts.text: High Court appeal from Original Decree No. 48 of 1949 arising from Judgment dated 22nd December 1948 of Subordinate Judge, 3rd Court, 24-Parganas in Title Suit No. 53 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from Original Decree No. 48 of 1949.arising out of Judgment and Decree dated the 22nd December, 1948, of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, 3rd Court,24-Parganas, in Title Suit No. 53 of 1944.

facts.text: Material facts not in dispute; controversy centers on whether suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The facts material for our present purpose are number in dispute and the companytroversy between the parties practically centres round one short point, namely, whether or number the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation.

facts.text: Subject-matter is one-third share of shebaiti right in private debutter of Dakshineshwar Jew at Dhop Dhopi, 24-Parganas, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of dispute is one-third share of shebaiti right in respect of a private debutter dedicated to an idol known by the name of Dakshineshwar Jew and situated at a village called Dhop Dhopi within the district of 24-Parganas in West Bengal.

facts.text: Deity founded by Udhab Chandra Pandit; rights vested in Iswar Chandra Chakroborti, common ancestor.

anchor.surface_text: The deity is an ancient one and its reputed founder and first shebait was one Udhab Chandra Pandit. It is number disputed that by successive devolutions the rights of the shebait came to vest in one Iswar Chandra Chakroborti,

facts.text: Iswar died leaving six sons: Ashutosh, Govinda, Gopal, Sadananda, Trailokhya, Haran.

anchor.surface_text: Iswar died leaving six sons as his heirs and they were Ashutosh, Govinda, Gopal, Sadananda, Trailokhya and Haran.

facts.text: Six sons divided shebaiti right into six equal shares by palas (5 days worship each per month).

anchor.surface_text: These six sons when they divided the properties of their father, divided the shebaiti right also which devolved upon them in six equal shares, and this division was by the method known as palas or turns of worship, which means that to each one of the sons was allotted the right of worshipping the deity for 5 days every month

facts.text: Govinda (father of plaintiffs) sold his 5 days pala to Haran, giving Haran one-third share (10 days).

anchor.surface_text: Gradually, a custom grew up in the family according to which these palas companyld be bought and sold or otherwise alienated amongst the members of the shebaits family. Govinda, who was the father of the plaintiffs and who got 5, days pala every month in his share, sold his interest in the shebaiti to Haran, a brother of his, and the result was that Haran acquired 10 days pala every mouth or one-third share in the entire shebaiti right.

facts.text: Haran died without issue, survived by widow Rajlakshmi as sole heir.

anchor.surface_text: Haran died without any issue leaving him surviving, his widow Rajlakshmi as his sole heir under the Hindu law and Rajlakshmi companytinued to hold this one- third share of shebaiti right along with other properties of the deceased.

facts.text: On 17th June 1920, Rajlakshmi granted ijara lease of shebaiti right for 2 years to Satish Chandra Dey.

anchor.surface_text: On 17th June, 1920, Rajlakshmi granted an ijara lease of her shebaiti right for a term of two years to one Satish Chandra Dey.

facts.text: On 1st April 1921, Satish sold leasehold interest to Ram Rakhal Ghose.

anchor.surface_text: On 1st of April, 1921, Satish sold this leasehold interest in respect to the palas to one Ram Rakhal Ghose.

facts.text: On 6th August 1920, Ram Rakhal took 5-year lease from Rajlakshmi commencing after Satish's lease.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to that, on 6th of August, 1920, Ram Rakhal had himself taken a lease from Rajlakshmi of her shebaiti right for a period of 5 years, this lease to companymence at the close of the previous lease in favour of Satish.

facts.text: Ram Rakhal got possession of shebait office from 1st April 1921.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Rakhal admittedly got possession of the office of shebait and began to exercise his rights as such on and from the 1st of April, 1921.

facts.text: On 7th November 1921, Rajlakshmi sold shebaiti right to Ram Rakhal.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of companyveyance dated the 7th of November, 1921, Rajlakshmi made an out and out sale of her shebaiti right in favour of Ram Rakhal

facts.text: On 27th November 1921, Ram Rakhal sold interest to Nagendra and Surendra, sons of Trailokhya.

anchor.surface_text: and twenty days after this purchase, that is to say, on 27th November, 1921, Ram Rakhal in his turn sold this interest to Nagendra and Surendra, two of the sons of Trailokhya.

facts.text: Surendra died; on 20th June 1925, widow Tarakali sold his share to Nagendra.

anchor.surface_text: Surendra died some time afterwards and on 20th of June, 1925, his widow Tarakali sold her husbands share in the shebaiti right to Nagendra, her husbands brother.

facts.text: Nagendra held entirety of one-third shebaiti right.

anchor.surface_text: Thus Nagendra in addition to what he had inherited from his own father came to hold the entirety of a third share in the shebaiti right, represented by 10 days pala every mouth, which was previously hold by Haran.

facts.text: Rajlakshmi died on 22nd December 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Rajlakshmi died on 22nd December, 1943,

facts.text: Plaintiffs (surviving sons of Govinda) filed Title Suit No. 53 of 1944 for possession of one-third shebaiti right as heirs of Haran.

anchor.surface_text: and the two plaintiffs, who are the two surviving sons of Govinda, filed the suit out of which this appeal arises for recovery of possession of this one-third shebaiti right of Haran on the allegation that they were the next heirs of Haran at the time of Rajlakshmis death.

facts.text: Defendant 1: Palani Bala, minor daughter of Nagendra, represented by husband.

anchor.surface_text: Nagendra had died in the meantime and the first and the principal defendant in the suit is his daughter Palani Bala, who is a minor and is represented by her husband as guardian.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed for plaintiffs on 22nd December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge by his judgment dated the 22nd December 1948, overruled the pleas taken by the defendant and gave the plaintiffs a decree.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court (Das and Guha JJ) reversed trial court on 19 June 1950, holding suit barred by limitation under Article 124.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment and decree of a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court dated June 19, 1950, reversing, on appeal, those of the Subordinate Judge... It was held by the High Court that the proper article to apply in this case was article 124 of the Limitation Act,

facts.text: Defendants contended sale by Rajlakshmi void, leading to adverse possession by Ram Rakhal et al.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted on behalf of defendant No. 1 and the main companytention raised was that as the sale of her shebaiti right by Rajlakshmi, the widow of Haran, was a void transaction which did number create any right in the transferee, the possession of Ram Rakhal and after him his vendees, who were the predecessors of defendant No. 1 , was adverse against all the shebaits,

facts.text: Plaintiffs claim reversionary rights to Haran's share after Rajlakshmi's death.

anchor.surface_text: for recovery of possession of this one-third shebaiti right of Haran on the allegation that they were the next heirs of Haran at the time of Rajlakshmis death. ... The case of the plaintiffs, in substance, is that the one- third share of the shebaiti right, which was held by Haran during his lifetime, devolved upon his widow Rajlakshmi who had only the restricted rights of a Hindu widow in respect to the same. On the death of the widow, the interest vested in the plaintiffs.
It was held by the High Court that the proper article to apply in this case was article 124 of the Limitation Act,

issues.text: whether or not the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: namely, whether or not the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation. The trial court decided this point in favour of the plaintiffs, while the High Court has taken a contrary view in appeal.

issues.text: whether on the facts of the present case the plaintiffs suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: The first is, whether on the facts of the present case the plaintiffs suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act ? If article 141 is the appropriate article, it is not disputed that the plaintiffs suit is well within time but if article 124 is applicable,

issues.text: when did the defendant or her predecessors take possession of the hereditary office of shebait adversely to the plaintiffs ? Was their possession adverse from the very date of the transfer by Rajlakshmi or did it become so only at her death ?

anchor.surface_text: the other point that would require consideration is, when did the defendant or her predecessors take possession of the hereditary office of shebait adversely to the plaintiffs ? Was their possession adverse from the very date of the transfer by Rajlakshmi or did it become so only at her death ?

issues.text: the proper article to apply in this case was article 124 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the High Court that the proper article to apply in this case was article 124 of the Limitation Act,

issues.text: whether the present suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the specific points raised in the case, the first thing that requires consideration is, whether the present suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act ?

issues.text: whether the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation under this article [124]

anchor.surface_text: and the question now arises as to whether the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation under this article, as has been held by the learned Judges of the High Court ?

arguments.claim: The suit is barred by limitation because the sale by Rajlakshmi was void and possession of Ram Rakhal and his vendees was adverse against all shebaits from the date of transfer

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted on behalf of defendant No. 1 and the main contention raised was that as the sale of her shebaiti right by Rajlakshmi, the widow of Haran, was a void transaction which did not create any right in the transferee, the possession of Ram Rakhal and after him his vendees, who were the predecessors of defendant No. 1 , was adverse against all the shebaits,

anchor.surface_text: On the question of limitation, the Subordinate Judge held that although article 141 of the Indian Limitation Act was not attracted to this case, yet the plaintiffs suit was not barred by limitation. Two reasons have been assigned for this view. It has been said in the first place that Nagendra purported to purchase only the life interest of Rajlakshmi consequently his position as purchaser was in recognition of the interest of the reversionary heirs of Haran.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court applied Art 124 with adverse possession

arguments.claim: Proper article is Art 124; possession adverse to plaintiff for more than 12 years; suit barred

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the High Court that the proper article to apply in this case was article 124 of the Limitation Act, and as the defendant No. 1 and her predecessors had been in possession of the hereditary office of the shebait adversely to the plaintiff for more than 12 years prior to the institution of the suit, the plaintiffs claim was barred by limitation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: article 141 companyld be claimed only if there was a qualified estate in the female heir after whose death the plaintiff was entitled to the property

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted Art 124 applies but rejected barred as adverse possession timing wrong

arguments.claim: Adverse possession against widow does not bar reversioners who do not derive title through her; principle since 1871 embodied in Art 141

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee appearing for the plaintiffs appellants has not assailed the correctness of this proposition of law his contention is that the possession of shebaiti right by defendant No. 1 and her predecessors might have been adverse against Rajlakshmi ever since the date of transfer and on the strength of such possession they might have acquired a statutory title against her in respect of the shebaiti interest but such adverse possession for more than the statutory period though it might bar the widow would not bar the reversioners who do not derive their title from or -through her. This, it is said, is the principle underlying the law of limitation in India ever since 1871 and article 141 of the Limitation Act expressly recognises and gives effect to it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a qualified estate in the female heir after whose death the plaintiff was entitled to the property as the heir of the last male holder. According to

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle applies even outside Art 141; reversioner's right is spes successionis

arguments.claim: Even if Art 124 applies, adverse possession against plaintiffs starts only at widow's death

anchor.surface_text: It is contended by Mr. Chatterjee that even if article 141 does not apply to the facts of the present case and article 124 is taken to be the appropriate article, the plaintiffs suit would be quite within time as the defendant or her predecessors must be held to have taken possession of the office of the shebait adversely to the present plaintiffs only when the widow died and not before that.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: includes any person from or through whom a plaintiff derives his right to sue. In answer to this, it is argued by Mr. Ghose that a shebait like a tru

arguments.court_reasoning: Per s.2(8), adverse to plaintiff or through whom derives title; reversioners not through widow

arguments.claim: No general principle that adverse possession against widow does not bar reversioners; only under Art 141 which does not apply here

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it has been argued by Mr. Panchanan Ghose that there is nothing like a general principle of law that adverse possession against a Hindu widow could not be reckoned as adverse possession against her reversionary- heirs. That, it is said, is only a special rule which rests entirely upon the particular provision of article 141 of the Limitation Act and is confined in its operation to cases which come within the purview of that article.

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle is general per Hindu law and limitation history

arguments.claim: Art 124 applies; possession adverse from transfer date against next holder regardless of title derivation

anchor.surface_text: According.to the learned counsel, article .124 is the proper article which governs this case and the possession of the transferee of, the shebaiti interest being admittedly adverse to -the, holder of the office at the date of the transfer, it would be adverse against the next holder also, notmatter whether strictly he derives his title from the previous holder or not.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tricted and in the second place, after her death the property goes number to her heirs but to the heirs of the last male owner. It is admitted that th

arguments.court_reasoning: Per s.2(8) and Gnanasambanda, must be adverse to plaintiff or predecessor in title

arguments.claim: Female shebait has no restricted powers like property widow; Art 141 not apply

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that in the case of a hereditary office like that of a shebait, the powers of a female shebait are in no way more restricted than those of a male shebait and as the trust estate during the incumbency of a female shebait resides in her completely and effectually as in a male trustee, the male trustee who comes after her cannot claim the benefit of the principle upon which article 141 of the Limitation Act is founded.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: article 141 companyld be claimed only if there was a qualified estate in the female heir after whose death the plaintiff was entitled to the property

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed Art 141 not apply but shebaiti right heritable with widow's estate characteristics

arguments.claim: Art 124 governs as shebaiti right is hereditary office, not immovable property under Art 141

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the specific points raised in the case, the first thing that requires consideration is, whether the present suit is governed by article 124 or article 141 of the Limitation Act ? ... We hold, therefore, that article 124 is the proper article to be applied

arguments.claim: Under Art 124, adverse possession must be to plaintiff or person through whom plaintiff derives title; starts at widow's death

anchor.surface_text: Reading article 124 of the Limitation Act along with section 2  8 , the conclusion is irresistible that to defeat the title of the plaintiff under article 124 it is necessary to establish that the defendant had taken possession of the office adversely to the plaintiff or somebody from or through whom the plaintiff derives his title, more than 12 years prior to the institution of the suit.

arguments.claim: Shebaiti right combines office and property; female holds widow's estate; Art 141 not apply as not immovable property

anchor.surface_text: Whatever might be said about the office of a trustee, which carries no beneficial interest with it, a shebaitship, as is now well settled, combines in it both the elements of office and property. ... Article 141 refers expressly to immovable property and not to property in the general sense of the word. on the other hand, it is quite settled that a shebaiti right is a hereditary office and as such comes within the express language of article 124 of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: Legislature changed law in 1871 with Art 142/141 to start limitation from widow's death for reversioners

anchor.surface_text: In 1871 a new Limitation Act was passed which repealed the earlier Act of 1859. Article 142 of this Act  which corresponds to article 141 of the present Act  expressly prescribed a period of limitation of 12 years for a suit by a Hindu entitled to possession of immovable property on the death of a Hindu female heir, the limitation to run from the time when the female heir died.

arguments.claim: Pre-1871 law (Shivagunga, Nobin Chunder) treated widow's possession as representing estate but changed by Art 141

anchor.surface_text: in the old Limitation Act  Act XXIV of 1859  there was no specific provision relating to suits by reversioners ... the principle of representation of the estate by the widow enunciated in the Shivagunga case.

holdings.text: Article 124 of the Limitation Act is the proper article to be applied to the present suit and not article 141.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that article 124 is the proper article to be applied, and the question now arises as to whether the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation under this article, as has been held by the learned Judges of the High Court ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shebaiti right is hereditary office expressly covered by Art 124; not immovable property under Art 141; specific provision prevails over general.

holdings.text: A shebaiti right combines elements of office and property and is a hereditary office within Article 124 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever might be said about the office of a trustee, which carries no beneficial interest with it, a shebaitship, as is now well settled, combines in it both the elements of office and property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled law; expressly fits Art 124 language; anomalous property not purely immovable.

holdings.text: Article 141 applies only to immovable property; shebaiti right does not come under immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: Article 141 refers expressly to immovable property and not to property in the general sense of the word.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading; shebaiti is peculiar anomalous property/office.

holdings.text: Under Article 124 read with Section 2(8), possession must be adverse to the plaintiff or person from or through whom the plaintiff derives title.

anchor.surface_text: Reading article 124 of the Limitation Act along with section 2(8), the conclusion is irresistible that to defeat the title of the plaintiff under article 124 it is necessary to establish that the defendant had taken possession of the office adversely to the plaintiff or somebody from or through whom the plaintiff derives his title,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation combining Art 124 and def of plaintiff in s2(8); affirmed in Gnanasambanda precedent.

holdings.text: Reversioners do not derive title through the widow; adverse possession against widow does not run against reversioners until her death.

anchor.surface_text: the reversioners right to property accrues on the death of the widow and not before that. ... The right of reversionary heirs is in the nature of spes successionis, and as the reversioners do not trace their title through or from the widow,

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle from Hindu law and limitation history since 1871; spes successionis; widow holds limited estate; not through her.

holdings.text: The suit is not barred by limitation under Article 124 as adverse possession against plaintiffs commenced only on Rajlakshmi's death on 22nd December 1943 and suit filed in 1944 is within 12 years.

anchor.surface_text: more than 12 years prior to the institution of the suit. ... and the question now arises as to whether the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation under this article, as has been held by the learned Judges of the High Court ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adverse possession timing per h4 and h5; facts show possession adverse to widow earlier but to reversioners only post-death; within 12 years.

holdings.text: Alienation of shebaiti right by shebait to stranger is absolutely void; alienee is trespasser from beginning.

anchor.surface_text: The proposition is well established that the alienation of the shebaiti right by a shebait in favour of a stranger is absolutely void in Hindu law and cannot be validated even on the footing of a custom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well established proposition; applied to facts.

holdings.text: Female shebait holds shebaiti right as widow's estate: heritable but reverts to heirs of last male holder, with restricted alienation.

anchor.surface_text: As the shebaiti interest is heritable and follows the line of inheritance from the founder obviously when the heir is a female, she must be deemed to have, what is known, as widows estate in the shebaiti interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heritable nature implies widow's estate characteristics; restrictions inherent in shebaiti but limited estate applies.

precedents.cited_proposition: adverse possession which bars the widow bars the heir after her

precedents.citation: Katama Natchier v. Rajah of Shivagunga 1861-63 9 Moo. I.A. 539

anchor.surface_text: 1861-63 9 Moo. I.A. 539. against her in regard to her estate is in the absence of fraud or companylusion binding on the reversionary heir. Turner L.J., who delivered the judgment of the Board, observed in companyrse of his judgment.

precedents.cited_proposition: decree fairly and properly obtained against Hindu widow binds reversionary heir
precedents.cited_holding: The whole estate would for the time be vested in her... a decree fairly and properly obtained would bind the reversionary interest

anchor.surface_text: The cause of action, it was said, accrued to the widow and Vide in this connection Jugal Kishore v. Jotendro. 11 A. 66. 73.  2  9 W.R. 505. a suit by her or by her reversioner must be brought within 12 years from the date of dispossession

anchor.surface_text: 9 W.R. 505. a suit by her or by her reversioner must be brought within 12 years from the date of dispossession as laid down in section 12 of the Limitation Act of 1859.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that article 124 is the proper article to be applied, and the question now arises as to whether the plaintiffs suit is barred by limitation under this article, as has been held by the learned Judges of the High Court ? Article 124 relates to a suit for possession of a hereditary office and the period of limitation prescribed for such suit is 12 years from the date when the defendant takes possession of the office adversely to the plaintiff. The intention of the legislature is obviously to treat hereditary office like land for the purpose of barring suits for possession of such office and extinguishing the right to the possession thereof

outcome.relief_summary: Plaintiffs' suit not barred by limitation under Article 124 as adverse possession not against plaintiffs until widow's death
